ORAL ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS

HOUGANG
(Building of primary schools)


    1. Mr Low Thia Khiang asked the Minister for Education whether his Ministry plans to build more primary schools in the vicinity of Hougang and, if so, when will they be completed.

     The Minister of State for Education (Dr Ker Sin Tze) (for the Minister for Education): Mr Speaker, Sir, the answer to Mr Low's Question is that the Ministry of Education plans to build a new primary school at Hougang Avenue 8. The construction will be completed by the end of 1994 and classes will commence in early 1995.

Column: 1009

HOUGANG CONSTITUENCY
(Projected intake of primary one students)


    2. Mr Low Thia Khiang asked the Minister for Education what is the projected intake of primary one students residing in the constituency of Hougang in 1993 and 1994.

     Dr Ker Sin Tze (for the Minister for Education): Mr Speaker, Sir, the Member for Hougang has asked the projected intake of primary one students residing in the constituency of Hougang in 1993 and 1994. The Ministry of Education does not plan student intake at the constituency level. It is planned according to a new town's demand for places. For 1993 and 1994, there will be about 3,500 primary one places provided by schools in Hougang New Town and the vicinity of the new town. This will be sufficient to meet the projected demand for about 2,500 places in 1993 and 2,900 places in 1994.

     Mr Low Thia Khiang (Hougang): Sir, is the Minister of State aware that the main primary schools in Hougang, namely, Holy Innocents and Xinghua, have problems in

Column: 1010

admitting students because they are over-populated? Will the Minister of State assure me that the children of Hougang will be able to be admitted to the schools in the vicinity of Hougang within 2 km from their residence?

     Dr Ker Sin Tze: According to the Ministry's estimate, the 3,500 places will be adequate to meet the demands for primary one student intake in 1993, 1994 and even 1995 because children born in the Dragon year will be admitted in 1995. We estimate that the demand by that time will be 3,420 but we have 3,500 places. So it is adequate to take care of all the demands.

    As to the number of schools, it is difficult to have so many schools within the constituency of Hougang. But in the Hougang New Town and the nearby areas, we have altogether about 11 schools with 88 classes. The total number of places will be adequate to meet the demand.

    As to whether students can go to school within the 2 km requirement, I think it is a bit difficult because of the location, building and the distribution of population. We try to provide places as close to the residence as possible. But physically, I am sure the Member for Hougang also appreciates that there is difficulty in setting up school at the doorstep of the students.

     Mr Peh Chin Hua (Jalan Besar GRC)( In Mandarin): Sir, last Friday, I mentioned that I welcome the Ministry of Education's decision to include sex education in the curriculum for Secondary 1 and Secondary 2 students from 1993. However, I hope that the Ministry of Education would complement the teaching of sex education with the inculcation of the correct values because if we were to teach sex education like a science subject or health science, then the effect may not be satisfactory. As such, we have to inculcate in our students the "moral values of sex", so that they would realize that behind "sex" there is this value of "responsibility" that they would have to bear in mind. They should not take sex lightly! This would prevent teenagers from committing sex-related crimes or indulging in casual sex, owing to their ignorance or curiosity in sex. This would also help our students to have a better understanding of the true meaning of "sex".

    On the other hand, I suggest that the teaching of sex education should be made as plain and simple as possible, such as the use of "educational video tapes". At the same time, I hope that when teaching this subject, the teachers would not avoid the important and dwell on the trivial, or simply touch on it lightly, giving the students only a hazy notion on the subject. The teachers should not tint the teaching of sex education with obscenity, to the detriment of the students. Otherwise, this will run contrary to the object of the sex education programme.

    We can also include an introduction on the cause and types of venereal diseases, and some of the common social problems such as promiscuity, abortion, pre-marital sex, etc. This would give the students a clearer picture of these problems and provide them with proper guidance in the way to look at these problems and how to deal with them.

    In short, we have to strike a balance between the conservative attitude of the East and the liberal thinking of the West towards sex, so that our students will not lose their directions in the midst of these

Column: 1012

two main trends. This is something we have to bear in mind when we commence the teaching of sex education.

    Sir, I would urge the Ministry of Education to seek the views from all quarters in its planning of the "sex education" programme so that the teaching of sex education would achieve its desired results.

     Mr R. Sinnakaruppan (Kampong Glam GRC): Sir, Singapore's dependence on human resources for its economic success cannot be over-stated. It is therefore not surprising that our Government spent a significant part of its expenditure on education.

    The primary aim of our school system is to develop each child to his or her fullest potential. In the report of the Review Committee on Improving Primary School Education, it has been pointed out that the primary school system has been successful in improving academic performance. However, improving academic performance alone is inadequate. One common criticism that still prevails is that our education system produces only "exam-smart" students. Perhaps this is the effect caused by the high premium placed by our society on academic success. The schools, the parents, and the peers place excessive pressure on a child to pass and excel in examinations. As a result, past years' papers and revision guide books have become the be-all and end-all for many students. Teachers, in their zeal to get their classes to perform well, tend to concentrate only on what they think is important for the examinations.

    Sir, undue emphasis placed by parents, teachers and students towards examinations will limit the development of our children to their fullest potential. We need to design a curriculum that would provide a broad-based education so that we can develop the inner faculties of our children. The school curriculum must provide ample opportunities to develop in our young thinking and analytical skills, creativity and confidence in self-expression. Parents and educationists to whom I have spoken are of the opinion that the present curriculum

Column: 1013

does not adequately promote the development of these qualities. Given the increased sophistication of our workplace and the constant struggle to increase productivity, the curriculum in school must lay the foundation for our workforce to be adaptable, resilient and innovative.

    I would like to ask the Minister how frequently the curriculum in our schools is reviewed and whether input is obtained from the market on the strengths and weaknesses of our workforce. I would also like to ask the Minister what efforts are being made to provide our students a more broad-based education.

     Mr Ho Peng Kee (Sembawang GRC): Sir, I declare my interest as Council Chairman of the National Police Cadet Corps which is the schools' ECA.

    Sir, the involvement in ECA is very important for the all-round balanced development of students in our schools, polytechnics and universities. This is especially so today with the emphasis on a fit and healthy lifestyle and the strengthening of communitarian values.

    Why are ECAs important? There are many reasons, but let me just focus on one which I think is important. This is that students learn and practise leadership and teamwork. They develop group identity and community spirit. In short, ECAs nurture the qualities of bonding and commitment which are essential for community life. This point is crucial in the context of today's Singapore. Bonding and commitment to each other as individuals, to the school and university as an institution, and to Singapore as home. This is why many SU and NUS graduates, who were active in ECA when they were undergraduates, feel an affinity to the institution. The more active you are, the prouder you are to be an alumnus. This, in my view, is an important key to developing strong alumni ties.

    ECA balances the pressure for academic excellence. This issue surfaced recently in two episodes - I think we know about them - the revision in the testing for primary school children and the junior college principals' agreement not to release their schools' results until after two

Column: 1014

weeks. There has been a lot of acrimony in the Straits Times as to the cause of this pressure and the focus has been on the schools, the school system and parents.

    However, instead of apportioning blame, I feel that the more productive approach is to see how various parties, each playing a part, can help to alleviate this pressure - the Ministry of Education, parents and a third party, in my view, which is important, is the employers. Collectively, if each of us can do something, I think a lot can be done.

    The Ministry of Education has made a start by revising the testing system for the Primary 3 children. In my view, the junior college principals have also made a start, putting aside the method that they have employed. I think we must not lose sight of the statement that they are trying to put across to Singaporeans: "Please do not judge our schools by academic standards alone." We have to look at this substance and not get lost in the clamour as to the correctness of the method.

    NUS has also made a start. We try to allow each undergraduate at least one year's stay in the hall of residence. In my mind, ECA can restore some balance to the system. Therefore, may I make an appeal to employers and parents. First, to employers. I urge all employers, and Government should take the lead, to include ECA as a factor for consideration in assessing job applications. In a way, the message will be received loud and clear on the ground.

    In a survey conducted last year, some employers opined that the graduates from a local university do not compare favourably with those who returned from overseas. Why is that so? It is because the criteria they chose for comparison, such as the ability to adapt to corporate culture, initiative, confidence and willingness to speak up, social skills and so on, bear no direct relation to paper grades. They are qualities which are best developed through active involvement in ECA. My message is therefore simple: if employers want better employees, they should pay greater attention to the ECA record of job applicants.

Column: 1015



    To fellow parents, just a short appeal. Let us not be over-protective of our children when it comes to ECA. It is natural for us as parents to be concerned. I am too. But I am sure parents will join me in saying that when we were ourselves school children, our parents were not so protective. And I do not think we have come out the worse for it; in fact, probably better.

    I wish to seek the Ministry's views on the importance of ECA as a ballast to academic pressure.

     Mr Low Thia Khiang (Hougang)( In Mandarin): Sir, as we all know, reading is a habit. It is a very important way to gain knowledge. But we often hear comments that Singaporeans do not have this habit of reading. The Government is also trying to encourage people to read more. I think the habit of reading should be cultivated from young. The school is the important base for the cultivation of this habit and the school library is the important bridge to cultivate the reading habit. However, in the Main and Development Estimates of the Ministry of Education, apart from funds allocated to libraries of junior colleges to be computerised, I do not see any budget provision for the expansion of school libraries. Does it mean that our school libraries are so well-equipped that there is no room for improvement?

    I would like to know how much has the Ministry of Education allocated to the school libraries to purchase books and what specific plan it has to encourage the students to make full use of the library, and to cultivate the habit of reading.

    With respect to extra-curricular activities (ECA), I suggest that the Ministry of Education include community service as part of the ECA programme for our secondary and junior college students, in order to encourage our secondary school students to participate in community service. This suggestion is in conformity with the Government's promotion of love and care among our fellow citizens. The Workers' Party has, since 1972, been advocating a "Caring Society" to remind Singaporeans

Column: 1016

to show more care and concern for the less for- tunate in our society.

    From newspaper reports, we learn that many charitable organisations are having difficulty getting volunteers to help them. Whether a person would voluntarily show care and concern for others, has a lot to do with his contacts and his experience in life. The cultivation of love for others should start from young. If the students, taking an active part in community service through their ECA involvement, can come to realize the true meaning of community service, and the fact that there are still many people in our society who are less fortunate than us, then they will value all the things they possess. It is possible that they will become volunteer social workers in future. I think this will have a positive effect on the development of the students' character, and the improvement to the general mood of our society.

     The Minister of State for Education (Dr Ker Sin Tze)( In Mandarin): Sir, the Member for Jalan Besar GRC has raised a number of issues, and they are all important issues. I would like to reply to his questions concerning the heavy school bags, loyalty to the school, and sex education.

    The question of school bags being too heavy may sound like a triviality. However, I tend to agree with the Member for Jalan Besar GRC that it is, in fact, a rather important matter, especially to the younger children. Every day they have to carry their extremely heavy school bags when they go to school. It may well have some adverse effect on their physical development. As far as the Ministry of Education is concerned, we agree with his view and we have advised the publishers of school textbooks to reduce the thickness and weight of the textbooks. Nowadays, all the primary school textbooks are divided into two volumes, one for each semester. This will help to reduce the weight of the textbooks.

    As for the installation of lockers in every classroom, I agree that this is a good suggestion. However, at the time when our present schools were built, there was no provision to equip the classrooms with

Column: 1017

lockers. Therefore, owing to space constraint, we are unable to equip the classrooms of our present schools with lockers for our primary school students to keep their books. However, the Ministry of Education will further study this matter and see whether something can be done to overcome this difficulty in future, or whether some alternative method can be worked out.

    Of course, to keep the books in school lockers has its advantages. However, on the other hand, it may also be useful for the students to bring their books home because they may need these books when they revise their lessons at home, and their parents can lend them a helping hand at that. So, if they leave their textbooks in the school lockers, they may forget to bring certain materials required for their revision at home. This may give rise to some problems too. As a matter of fact, the parents should help their young children, particularly those in Primary 1 and 2, aged 6 or 7 years old, decide which books should be brought to school and which could be kept at home. Personally, I have a young child. I asked him why he was bringing all his textbooks to school. He told me, with some embarrassment, that he had lost the time table. That is the first point. Secondly, there is only one period of health education in a week. But he brings the health education book to school everyday, so that it is always there when he needs it. He does not know which book ought to be taken out, and which book has to be brought to school. If the parents can spend some time to help them decide which are the books to be brought to school, and which are the ones that could be left out, then it will help to reduce the weight of the school bag. At the same time, I hope that the teachers would not penalise or punish the school children simply because they forget to bring a particular book to school on a certain day. In fact, the teachers should allow them to share the book with their classmates. In this way, the problem of heavy school bags may be alleviated, although it cannot be resolved completely. If there are constructive and practical suggestions or recommendations to resolve the matter,

Column: 1018

the Ministry of Education will be only too pleased to consider and adopt them.

    The second subject is how to inculcate a sense of loyalty to the school. A sense of loyalty to the school is very important because whether a school can be developed well or not depends not only on the students, their parents, but also very much on the former students or old boys of the school. Their love and concern for the school will go a long way in helping the school to develop and progress. For the old-boys to care for their alma mater, they must first of all have good sentimental feelings for the school, and that the school is also concerned about them.

    The Member for Jalan Besar GRC put forward two points - first, preserve the old school buildings and, secondly, avoid frequent transfer or changes of principals and teachers. Let me first deal with the preservation of old school buildings. According to my survey, I find that very few schools are being built at their original site where the old buildings were demolished. Up to now, there are only five schools which were built at their former sites. At the moment, there are two schools, namely Raffles Girls' School and Crescent Girls' School, which have been moved temporarily to other places pending the completion of their new school buildings at their original sites.

    New schools are mostly located in new HDB housing estates because there is generally a lack of enrolment in the older residential areas as young people have moved out to set up their families in new towns. Therefore, new schools have to be built in new housing estates to cater for the rising demand for student places in new housing estates. However, in order to maintain the feelings of the old boys for their alma mater, these "new" schools in the new HDB estates retain the old names of schools moved in from elsewhere. Ai Tong School, as mentioned by the Member for Jalan Besar GRC, belongs to this category. It was built at a new site, not at its original site. As far as possible, the

Column: 1019

Ministry of Education always tries its best to preserve the old school buildings. However, when we relocate an old school to a new site in a HDB new town, we surely cannot move the old school building there.

    In preserving the old buildings, of course, the Ministry of Education would also take into consideration the cost of renovation, and whether it is worthwhile to do so. Sometimes, the renovation cost could be even more than the cost of constructing a new school building.

    The other limb of this subject is on the frequent transfer of school principals and teachers. Whenever possible, the Ministry of Education will not transfer the principal and teachers of one school to another. However, sometimes, such a transfer cannot be avoided because there may be vacancies in certain schools which need to be filled urgently, or teachers for certain subjects are lacking in some schools and we have to source for such teachers from other schools. Sometimes, it is the teachers themselves who ask for transfer because of some personal reasons.

    As far as the Ministry of Education is concerned, we try our best not to transfer the principals and teachers, whenever possible. Mr Peh mentioned that when old boys went back to the school they could not find the familiar faces of their old teachers. Perhaps, he might have forgotten that we all grow old with every passing year. Principals and teachers have to retire when they reach a certain age. Then, of course, you cannot go back to the school and expect to find the principal or teachers who taught you during your school days. As far as the inculcation of a sense of loyalty to the school is concerned, I think we should have more organised activities. I remember that in the past, some Chinese schools had this combined school sports meet or inter-school debates, swimming carnival, etc. I think these activities may be useful in establishing closer links between the old boys and their alma mater, and hence their sense of loyalty to the school.

Column: 1020



    The third issue raised by Mr Peh is an interesting issue, that is, sex education in school. The Ministry of Education agrees that sex education should be taught in conjunction with the teaching of moral education. If sex education is being taught merely as a health science, then it will not be effective in guiding the students on how to properly treat the problem of sex in future. Sex is quite a personal matter. In the past, people were reluctant to teach this subject and to discuss it openly. But now we realise the importance of sex education. We have to teach it as part of life and family education, so even in the primary school there is some mention of sex education to the pupils. In the secondary schools we will be introducing more topics relating to sex education to the students. But this will not be taught as a subject. It will be incorporated in other moral education or civic lessons to the pupils. Of course, we would also emphasise the importance of moral education when we teach sex education in school.

    Mr Peh expressed concern on whether pornographic video-tapes would be used as a teaching aid for sex education. I can give him the assurance that the Ministry of Education will never allow the use of pornographic video-tapes as a teaching aid.

     The Minister of State for Education (Encik Sidek bin Saniff): Sir, Mr Sinnakaruppan has raised three important questions.

    First, curriculum in the schools. Sir, curriculum review is an on-going process. Feedback is obtained by school inspectors and subject specialists on their school visits as well as during school appraisal. However, the curriculum is normally revised once in every eight to ten years or as and when the need arises, to match the pace of socio- economic development in Singapore.

    Feedback from various Ministries and departments, especially from the Ministry

Column: 1021

of Trade and Industry, the National Productivity Board and Public Service Commission, as well as the private sector, through representation on various Government committees set up to monitor Singapore's economic performance, is taken into account when reviewing our school curriculum. For instance, the emphasis placed on enhancing students' proficiency in English Language and Mathematics is directly in response to feedback from the market, on the strengths and weaknesses of the current workforce. This is also the case for the computer literacy programmes in all secondary schools to enable every student to be computer literate by the time he completes his secondary education and the school curriculum is geared closely to meeting the changing needs for a workforce that can meet the challenges of changes in Singapore's business and industry.

    The second question is about a broad-based education, Sir. Our school curriculum is designed to provide a broad-based education for all students, with equal emphasis on students' intellectual, physical, aesthetic and moral development. Conscious efforts are made to create a total learning environment in our schools to provide a balance between the academic and non-academic subjects to stimulate students' intellectual, physical and emotional growth, as well as to equip them with the necessary life-skills, as responsible citizens able to lead a fulfilling life as a valuable member of Singapore's future workforce. A wide range of academic subjects, like the Languages, Mathematics, Literature, History, Geography, and non-academic subjects, like Art and Craft, Social Studies, Home Economics, Civics and Moral Education, Physical Training, Design and Technology, etc., are included in the curriculum. Students are also required to participate in extra-curricular activities (ECA) of their choice. This provides opportunities for social interaction and develops leadership skills (eg, in the participation of uniformed groups, such as Scouts, NPCC, NCC, Red Cross, Girl Guides), as well as sports (eg, tennis, netball, soccer, rugby), clubs (eg, Interact Club, Arts and Social Club, etc.), and

Column: 1022

societies (eg, Literary, Debating and Dramatic Society, or in Chinese/Malay/Tamil Cultural and Language Society).

    Sir, the third one is even more important and has something to do with examination. My colleague had mentioned it on Friday, but let me re-emphasise. Examination is a yardstick by which to assess students' performance. Equal emphasis is placed on developing in every student life-long learning and social skills which can be applied even after they leave school. That is the thrust of the whole thing. Our instructional materials are designed to inculcate thinking skills, which equip students with analytical and creative thinking processes in decision-making and problem solving. Through structured instructional programmes designed to encourage cooperation and group work in class assignments as well as out-of-school activities, like field trips and project works, students learn to be tolerant and appreciate the contribution of others in achieving group success. In other words, each one of them must understand the psyche and conundrum in the Malay, the Chinese and the Indian side. Our students have performed well in pursuing further studies as well as in their working life, both locally and overseas.

    Sir, I now turn to the question made by Mr Ho Peng Kee. I cannot agree more with his deliberation. I can sum up the whole deliberation by stating our objective for the ECA in schools and tertiary levels as well. First, ECA provides opportunities for pupils and tertiary students to keep physically fit and mentally alert through healthy recreation. Second, the health nurtures qualities in pupils and tertiary students, such as discipline, confidence and cooperation and promotes leadership skills, organisational skills and, most of all, teamwork or esprit de corps because without esprit de corps, the society collapses. They also aid in the moral, cultural and aesthetic development of pupils and tertiary students, thus contributing to well-rounded and complete persons.

    Mr Ho also called upon the employers to include ECA for assessing job applicants.

Column: 1023

I hope the employers will take note. In fact, when he advised parents not be over-protective of our students, I must say that there are about seven constraints in the implementation of ECA programme. Out of these seven constraints, four have something to do with parents. I will just give you examples. First, conflicting demands for pupils' time by parents, class teachers and teachers in charge of ECA. Second, parental objection arising from the desire for their children to do well in their examination. Third, protective parents who are not prepared to let their children to be exposed to adventurous activities. Finally, reluctance of parents to allow their young children to travel on their own to school for ECAs held outside school hours. I would like to urge --

     Mr Low Thia Khiang: Sir, a point of clarification.
